content.body: Question about https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10673: would those modules also be importable through JS `import ... with { type: "css" }`? Or is the reason we are talking about the import map something else?
content.formatted_body: Question about https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10673: would those modules also be importable through JS import ... with { type: "css" }? Or is the reason we are talking about the import map something else?

content.body: Andreu Botella: remind me, was there some good solution for the sync cross-origin asyncContext case?
content.formatted_body: Andreu Botella: remind me, was there some good solution for the sync cross-origin asyncContext case?

content.body: nicolo-ribaudo: I think the idea is that they would be when you use the specifier, yes
content.formatted_body: nicolo-ribaudo: I think the idea is that they would be when you use the specifier, yes

content.body:
> <@smaug:mozilla.org> Andreu Botella: remind me, was there some good solution for the sync cross-origin asyncContext case?

The solution so far would be to switch to an empty context before firing the cross-origin event, but I still need to investigate this in more detail
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @smaug:mozilla.org
Andreu Botella: remind me, was there some good solution for the sync cross-origin asyncContext case?
The solution so far would be to switch to an empty context before firing the cross-origin event, but I still need to investigate this in more detail

content.body: hmm, how do we know something is cross-origin event?
I guess one could have something on stack and when trying to access it do some check. Maybe that works.
and the new realm would effectively need to push something to stack and once done, pop
